value.text: Memory game Numerical families (Part I)

text:
Prerequisites

The text on this page aims to reinforce knowledge of indigenous numerical systems and the numbers we use today. Before starting, we suggest studying the following previous pages:

• Our sides are equal: in this first text, we show for people their body symmetry.
  • Couting: we introduce the idea of counting using our body.
  • Beyond fingers: exploring the limitations and the necessity of new tools to count.

Introduction

We learned that when it is not possible to count using just our fingers, we can ask for help from other people. However, sometimes this is still not enough (History Tracers, , Además de los Dedos).

Reflection 2: The limits
When can we raise all fingers to represent a number?
The first step to address this reflection is to summarize what we have learned:

• When we click the up arrow (blue arrow), the numbers increase up to 9.
  • When we click the down arrow (green arrow), the numbers decrease down to 0.

We can conclude that values increase to a maximum limit of nine (9) and decrease to a minimum value of zero (0). These are the limits per position that a number can have in the decimal numerical system, and we must respect them.
Looking at Table 1, we see that when we needed help counting with our hands, other people stood beside us raising their fingers. We can do the same with numbers, respecting their limits:
Second personFirst personHindu-ArabicHindu-ArabicArrows
Table 3: The logic of numbers

The zero (0) represents the concept of emptiness (Musa, Auwalu, , pp. 44, 46 - 48). Therefore, we do not write zeros on the left side of other numbers, but we can consider that zeros are there. With this in mind, when we reach the maximum (9) in a position, we increase the next value to one, and reset the current position to zero.
We could continue using the arrows to have numbers greater than nineteen (19), but on this page, we will focus only on these numbers. On the next pages, we will work with larger numbers.

Extending the numerical system

Besides the decimal system, indigenous peoples created another system, the vigesimal (Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , (ResearchGate), pp. 25 - 26 ; Casares Contreras, Orlando & Cetina, José & Cabrera, Venus Sarahí, , (Revista), pp. 25-26 ; Puente, Francisco Barriga, , pp. 32, 34 ; Hernández Mendoza, Aurelio & Pérez López, Felipa, , pp. 251 - 260), which has symbols that can be associated with our toes. Conclusion

On this page, we learned how to create larger numbers, but we limited ourselves to representing numbers that can be associated with our fingers. These numbers have names without a well-defined pattern. On the next pages, we will learn about the connection of numbers with our families.
